data.title: How Investors Are Reacting To Sierra Madre Gold and Silver (TSXV:SM) La Guitarra Capacity Expansion Plan
data.description:

  • The company’s stepped-up investment in scoop trams, drills, haulage trucks, and loaders highlights a focus on improving mine development rates and material movement alongside the processing expansion.
  • We’ll now examine how the planned lift in La Guitarra’s processing capacity could shape Sierra Madre Gold and Silver’s investment narrative.

What Is Sierra Madre Gold and Silver's Investment Narrative?

To own Sierra Madre Gold and Silver, you have to believe La Guitarra can transition from a successful restart into a scaled, efficient producer without eroding shareholder value. The recent expansion update is central to that story, because it moves the company from talking about growth to actually pouring capital into mills, fleet and tailings to lift processing capacity over the next couple of years. In the short term, this adds a tangible catalyst around meeting staged throughput targets, but it also magnifies near term execution and cost risks at a time when the share price has already run very hard and volatility is elevated. Combined with recent equity financing, the expansion plan may reshape how investors weigh dilution, valuation and operational delivery in the months ahead.

However, one of the biggest issues now is how rising capital needs interact with an already rich sales multiple. Despite retreating, Sierra Madre Gold and Silver's shares might still be trading above their fair value and there could be some more downside. Discover how much.

data.title: Is It Too Late To Consider M/I Homes (MHO) After Its Strong Multi Year Rally?
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether M/I Homes is still good value after a strong multi year run, this article walks through how its current share price stacks up against several valuation measures.
  • The stock closed at US$140.40 recently, with returns of 4.8% over 30 days, 9.8% year to date and 17.9% over 1 year. The 3 year return sits at a very large 138.7%, and the 5 year return at 180.7%.

This context helps explain why the stock’s multi year performance and more recent moves remain in focus for many shareholders.

M/I Homes delivered 17.9% returns over the last year. See how this stacks up to the rest of the Consumer Durables industry.

Approach 1: M/I Homes Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model projects a company’s future cash flows and then discounts them back to today’s dollars to estimate what the business might be worth right now.

For M/I Homes, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach, based on cash flow projections. The latest twelve month free cash flow is about $137.9 million. Simply Wall St then extends analyst style estimates out to 2035, with projected free cash flow figures in the range of about $115.6 million in 2026 and $100.5 million in 2035, and discounts each of those back to today using its own assumptions.

Adding those discounted cash flows together and accounting for a terminal value gives an estimated intrinsic value of about $53.33 per share. Against a recent share price of US$140.40, the model implies the stock is 163.2% above this DCF estimate, which indicates M/I Homes is heavily overvalued on this specific cash flow based view.

Result: OVERVALUED

Approach 2: M/I Homes Price vs Earnings

For a profitable company like M/I Homes, the P/E ratio is a straightforward way to compare what you are paying for each dollar of earnings with other stocks. Investors usually accept a higher P/E when they expect stronger growth and lower perceived risk, and a lower P/E when growth expectations are more modest or risks are higher.

M/I Homes currently trades on a P/E of 8.98x. That sits below the Consumer Durables industry average of 13.20x and also below the peer average of 14.93x, which on simple comparisons can make the shares look inexpensive relative to similar businesses.

Simply Wall St’s Fair Ratio for M/I Homes is 13.31x. Q4 2025 revenue of US$47.9 million compares with US$66.17 million a year earlier and full year revenue of US$93.96 million compares with US$607.03 million, yet the company reported Q4 net income of US$65.06 million versus a net loss of US$5.05 million and full year net income of US$141.87 million versus US$70.52 million. data.title: Info Tech Systems SGX ITS Margin Slippage Challenges Bullish High Profitability Narrative
data.description:
Info-Tech Systems (SGX:ITS) has just posted its FY 2025 first half numbers, with revenue at S$22.4 million and basic EPS of S$0.0228, compared with S$21.4 million of revenue and S$0.0295 EPS in the first half of FY 2024. Over the trailing twelve months, total revenue moved from S$38.1 million in the second half of FY 2023 to S$56.5 million in FY 2025, while basic EPS shifted from S$0.0466 to S$0.0582. This gives investors a clear view of how the top line and per share earnings have evolved. With net profit margins slightly lower than last year and earnings growth outpacing revenue, the story here is about how efficiently Info-Tech Systems is converting a relatively modest revenue base into profit.

See our full analysis for Info-Tech Systems.

With the headline results on the table, the next step is to see how these numbers stack up against the key stories investors usually focus on, and where the latest figures reinforce or challenge those views.

Curious how numbers become stories that shape markets? Explore Community Narratives

Advertisement

TTM earnings up 21.7% on modest 1.6% revenue growth

  • Over the last 12 months, revenue grew by about 1.6% a year while earnings for that period rose 21.7%, so profit expanded much faster than the top line.
  • Bulls often like this kind of spread between revenue and earnings, and here that view leans on hard numbers:
    • TTM net income moved from S$10.49 million in the second half of FY 2023 to S$15.02 million in FY 2025, alongside revenue moving from S$38.06 million to S$56.49 million over the same points.
    • Supporters can point out that even though revenue growth is described as modest at 1.6% a year, the 21.7% earnings lift shows Info-Tech is extracting more profit from each dollar of sales.

Strong earnings growth against slower sales can be a key part of the bull story, and it is worth seeing how that is shaping the current debate on Info-Tech Systems. 📊 Read the what the Community is saying about Info-Tech Systems.

Margins slip from 28.2% to 26.6% while still staying high

  • Net profit margin for the trailing 12 months sits at 26.6%, compared with 28.2% the year before, so profitability per dollar of revenue has eased a little while remaining above a quarter of sales.
  • Critics focus on this margin movement when they question how durable the recent earnings strength really is:
    • The shift from 28.2% to 26.6% means a smaller share of the larger S$56.49 million revenue pool is dropping to the bottom line than previously, even though total earnings are higher.
    • For a software name where high margins matter, any margin compression gives bears something concrete to watch, especially when paired with only 1.6% annual revenue growth.

P/E of 17.2x and analyst target of S$1.24 vs S$1.00 price

  • Info-Tech trades on a trailing P/E of 17.2x, below the Asian software industry average of 22.9x and a peer average of 28.4x. Analysts’ S$1.24 price target sits above the current S$1.00 share price and implies about 24% upside.
  • What stands out is how this valuation discussion balances against the growth profile:
    • On one side, the lower P/E than industry and peers supports the idea that the stock is priced more cheaply relative to its earnings than many software names, even after a 21.7% lift in earnings over the past year.
    • On the other, revenue and earnings are both forecast to grow more slowly than the broader Singapore market, at 1.6% and 2.2% per year respectively versus 4.4% and 7.4%. Any case that the shares deserve a higher multiple rests on investors being comfortable with that slower growth profile.

Next Steps

data.title: Eastman Chemical Results Highlight Cash Strength Recycling Progress And Dividend Questions

data.title: Vistra Bets On Gas And Nuclear To Power Data Center Demand
data.description:
• Vistra (NYSE:VST) has committed around $4 billion to acquire natural gas and nuclear power plants, targeting rising electricity needs from data centers.
  • The company reports significant growth in EBITDA and dividends alongside this expansion in generation assets.
  • These moves mark a shift in Vistra's business mix toward serving large, power intensive customers such as data centers.

Vistra, a major US power producer and retailer, is leaning into the surge in electricity demand tied to data center build outs. By adding natural gas and nuclear capacity, NYSE:VST is increasing its exposure to dispatchable power that can serve round the clock loads. For investors, the mix of large asset purchases and higher dividends puts both capital allocation and balance sheet decisions in focus.

The company is positioning itself to be a key supplier to data centers that require reliable, large scale power. The combination of new generation assets and a growing dividend stream gives investors several angles to watch, from cash flow stability to how effectively Vistra integrates and operates its expanded fleet.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for Vistra by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on Vistra.

2 things going right for Vistra that this headline doesn't cover.

For Vistra, committing around US$4b to natural gas and nuclear assets is a clear push toward long term, contract backed cash flows from power intensive customers such as data centers. These plants can run consistently, which lines up with the 24/7 needs of hyperscalers and large corporates. The reported 13.9% growth in adjusted EBITDA over the first nine months of 2025 sits alongside a dividend profile that includes a common dividend with a five year compound annual growth rate of 10.7% and a preferred Series A payout of US$80.00 per share on an annualized basis. That combination suggests management is comfortable returning more cash to shareholders while still writing large checks for acquisitions. For you as an investor, the key question is whether the earnings base from these acquired assets and power contracts can comfortably service higher interest costs, ongoing capital spending, and both common and preferred dividends over time.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The Vistra Narrative

  • The data center driven acquisitions and new power purchase agreements tie directly into the narrative that rising electricity demand and long duration contracts can support revenue growth and EBITDA expansion.
  • Heavier use of acquisitions and fossil fuel assets, plus a higher leverage profile around 3x adjusted EBITDA, echoes the narrative’s caution that debt and regulatory pressure on gas and nuclear could constrain future margins.
  • The recent step up in common and preferred dividends is not fully reflected in the narrative and adds another layer of capital allocation that could influence how much cash is left for renewables and storage projects.

Knowing what a company is worth starts with understanding its story. Check out one of the top narratives in the Simply Wall St Community for Vistra to help decide what it's worth to you.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ⚠️ Interest payments are not well covered by earnings, which could limit financial flexibility if borrowing costs stay high or new projects run over budget.
  • ⚠️ Profit margins of 5.6% compared to 11.4% last year indicate pressure on profitability, which may matter if power prices or plant availability move against Vistra.
  • 🎁 Vistra is assessed as trading at a large discount to one estimate of fair value, which some investors may see as providing a margin of safety if the thesis on data center demand plays out.
  • 🎁 Earnings are forecast to grow 24.84% per year, so if acquisitions and long term contracts perform as planned, the current investment and dividend strategy could be supported by a rising earnings base.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, you may want to watch how quickly the newly acquired natural gas and nuclear plants are integrated, what returns Vistra reports on that US$4b outlay, and how stable EBITDA looks as more data center contracts come online. data.title: Kering Reweights Brand Portfolio As Gucci Reset Tests Group Resilience
data.description:
• Kering (ENXTPA:KER) is reshaping its brand portfolio as Gucci works through a reset in its positioning and product offering.
  • The group is putting more emphasis on labels such as Saint Laurent and Bottega Veneta while broader luxury demand shows signs of cooling.
  • This shift marks an important phase for Kering as it adjusts to changing consumer patterns in key luxury markets.

Kering, through brands like Gucci, Saint Laurent and Bottega Veneta, is a major player in global luxury fashion and accessories. With Gucci facing a reset, the group is looking more closely at how each house contributes to its overall profile at a time when demand for high end products is less buoyant than in recent years.

For you as an investor, the focus now is on how Kering balances Gucci’s turnaround efforts with the growing visibility of its other brands. The way the group allocates attention and resources across its portfolio could influence its resilience to changes in consumer spending in its core regions.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for Kering by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on Kering.

1 thing going right for Kering that this headline doesn't cover.

This brand reset puts Kering’s business model under the spotlight because so much of its cash generation and market perception has historically been linked to Gucci. As Gucci works through a repositioning, management is effectively asking the rest of the portfolio to carry more weight. For you, the key question is whether houses like Saint Laurent and Bottega Veneta can deepen their identity without diluting group focus or stretching creative and operational resources at a time when luxury demand is less buoyant.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The Kering Narrative

  • The increased emphasis on multiple houses lines up with the narrative of product refreshes and store optimization. These are aimed at sharpening brand positioning and improving operating leverage over time.
  • Execution risk at Gucci and other brands, already highlighted in the narrative, is reinforced by this reset. More creative shifts and portfolio changes raise the chance that some collections or market bets do not resonate with consumers.
  • The current news focuses on brand mix and positioning, while the narrative also points to factors like tourism trends and secondhand luxury, which may not be fully reflected in how investors interpret this reset.

Knowing what a company is worth starts with understanding its story. Check out one of the top narratives in the Simply Wall St Community for Kering to help decide what it's worth to you.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ⚠️ Execution risk around Gucci’s repositioning and other creative shifts, which could affect demand if new collections do not connect with core and aspirational buyers.
  • ⚠️ Analysts have flagged that Kering’s interest payments are not well covered by earnings. This can limit flexibility if trading conditions stay soft or turn weaker.
  • 🎁 Analysts expect earnings to grow strongly over the coming years. This suggests upside if Kering’s portfolio reset and cost discipline play out as planned.
  • 🎁 A stronger role for brands like Saint Laurent and Bottega Veneta could reduce reliance on a single label and help Kering compete more evenly with peers such as LVMH and Hermès.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, it is worth watching how quickly Gucci’s refreshed positioning shows up in product traction, pricing, and brand heat, especially with US aspirational shoppers. You can also track whether Saint Laurent, Bottega Veneta, and other houses gain more visibility in key regions without eroding Kering’s overall margin profile. data.title: Zeta Global Holdings (ZETA) Returns To Quarterly Profit, Testing Longstanding Skepticism On Profitability Path
data.description:
Zeta Global Holdings (ZETA) closed FY 2025 with Q4 revenue of US$394.6 million and basic EPS of US$0.03, alongside net income of US$6.5 million, setting a clear marker after a year that started in the red. Over the past four quarters, the company reported revenue increasing from US$314.7 million in Q4 2024 to US$394.6 million in Q4 2025, while basic EPS moved from US$0.07 to US$0.03. Trailing twelve month EPS stood at a loss of US$0.13, so the latest quarterly profit comes against a year that was still loss making in aggregate. For investors, this mix of quarterly profitability with loss making trailing results puts the focus squarely on how margins are evolving beneath the headline growth story.

See our full analysis for Zeta Global Holdings.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings report aligns with the prevailing narratives around Zeta’s growth, profitability path, and execution risks.

See what the community is saying about Zeta Global Holdings

Advertisement

US$1.3b trailing revenue with losses still on the books

  • On a trailing twelve month basis, Zeta reported about US$1.3b in revenue and a net loss of US$31.5 million, so the Q4 profit of US$6.5 million sits within a year that was still loss making overall.
  • Consensus narrative highlights strong adoption of AI marketing tools and first party data, and this snapshot partly fits that story, but:
    • Revenue in the trailing set has moved from US$901.4 million to US$1.3b, while losses narrowed from US$120.3 million to US$31.5 million, so the business is still absorbing costs even as it scales.
    • Analysts in that consensus view expect revenue growth to continue, yet the current trailing loss means the path from growth to steady profitability is not yet visible in the historical numbers alone.

Strong revenue and shrinking losses look encouraging, but the fact that the last 12 months still show a net loss keeps the focus on how quickly the model can turn that scale into consistent profits. 📊 Read the what the Community is saying about Zeta Global Holdings.

  • Zeta is trading on a P/S of 3.4x compared with a peer average of 5.5x and a US Software average of 3.5x, and the provided DCF fair value of US$30.27 sits above the current share price of US$17.85.
  • Bulls argue that faster earnings growth and margin improvement could justify that gap, and the current data partially lines up with that, but also raises questions:
    • The bullish view references shrinking losses at about 19.6% per year over five years and strong forecast earnings growth, which ties back to the trailing loss of US$31.5 million being much smaller than the earlier US$120.3 million loss in the dataset.
    • At the same time, with the company still loss making on a trailing basis, the lower P/S and the DCF fair value of US$30.27 versus US$17.85 depend on those future margin gains actually coming through, rather than on current profitability.

If you want to see how optimistic investors connect these numbers to their upside case, check out how they frame the opportunity in 🐂 Zeta Global Holdings Bull Case

  • Even after Q4’s US$6.5 million profit, the trailing twelve month figures still show a basic EPS loss of US$0.13 and total net loss of US$31.5 million, which bearish investors point to when they question the durability of the model.
  • Bears focus on data privacy, client concentration, and heavy tech spend, and the current figures give them some support alongside some pushback:
    • The ongoing trailing loss and prior quarterly losses of US$21.6 million, US$12.8 million, and US$3.6 million in FY 2025 help skeptics argue that investments in AI and data infrastructure have yet to translate into stable bottom line results.
    • On the other hand, the move from a US$120.3 million loss in an earlier trailing period to US$31.5 million in the latest snapshot suggests the cost base and revenue scale are at least moving closer to the profitability point that bearish forecasts still treat as uncertain.

data.title: Is It Too Late To Consider Ubiquiti (UI) After Its 123% One Year Surge?
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether Ubiquiti's current share price reflects its true worth, this article walks through the key numbers so you can judge the value story for yourself.
  • Ubiquiti's share price recently closed at US$755.43, with returns of 6.8% over 7 days, 37.6% over 30 days, 33.4% year to date, 123.4% over 1 year, 192.3% over 3 years, and 143.0% over 5 years. These figures raise fair questions about what is already priced in and how risk is being viewed.
  • Recent coverage of Ubiquiti has focused on its role in networking and wireless equipment markets, as investors look for companies with established product ecosystems and recognizable brands. This context helps frame why the stock has attracted attention alongside its recent price performance.
  • On our valuation checks Ubiquiti scores 1 out of 6, indicating it appears undervalued on only one of the six metrics we use. You can see the breakdown in this valuation score. Next, we will compare several common valuation approaches before finishing with a framework that can help you interpret these results in a more complete way.

Ubiquiti scores just 1/6 on our valuation checks. See what other red flags we found in the full valuation breakdown.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Ubiquiti Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model estimates what a company might be worth today by projecting future cash flows and then discounting those back into present value using a required return.

For Ubiquiti, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach. The latest twelve months Free Cash Flow is reported at about US$699 million. Simply Wall St then extends this with cash flow projections out to 2035, starting with an estimate of US$663.2 million in 2026 and US$743.3 million in 2035, with intermediate years in between. Analysts typically provide forecasts for up to five years, so the later years are extrapolated from earlier trends.

When all those projected cash flows are discounted back to today, the DCF model produces an estimated intrinsic value of US$197.14 per share. With the recent share price at US$755.43, this particular model implies the stock is very expensive relative to its cash flow estimate, with an intrinsic discount indicating it is about 283.2% above the DCF value.

Result: OVERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Ubiquiti may be overvalued by 283.2%. Discover 53 high quality undervalued stocks or create your own screener to find better value opportunities.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Ubiquiti.

Approach 2: Ubiquiti Price vs Earnings

For a profitable company like Ubiquiti, the P/E ratio is a useful way to think about value because it links what you are paying directly to the earnings the business is currently generating.

What counts as a normal or fair P/E depends on how the market views the company’s growth potential and risk. Higher expected growth or lower perceived risk can support a higher P/E, while slower growth or higher risk usually justifies a lower one.

Ubiquiti currently trades on a P/E of 51.45x. That sits above the Communications industry average P/E of about 40.47x, yet below the peer group average of 77.85x. To refine this further, Simply Wall St uses a proprietary “Fair Ratio” of 36.24x for Ubiquiti, which is an estimate of the P/E that would fit its specific earnings growth profile, industry, profit margins, market cap and risk characteristics.

This Fair Ratio is more tailored than a simple peer or industry comparison because it adjusts for company specific qualities instead of assuming that all businesses in a sector should trade at similar multiples.

Comparing Ubiquiti’s actual P/E of 51.45x with the Fair Ratio of 36.24x suggests the shares are pricing in more optimism than the model supports.

Result: OVERVALUED

Because Narratives sit on the platform used by millions of investors, you can see how others frame the same numbers, and the system keeps those Narratives updated when new information such as earnings reports or major news is added, so your fair value view stays current without extra effort.
